Trees¶

harrison_functions.collections.trees.balanced_root_from_sorted_array(array)¶
Returns the root of a tree constructed from a sorted array
Recursively and manually set the links
>>> balanced_root_from_sorted_array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7])

        4
     /     \
    2       6
  /  \     /  \
 1    3   5    7

harrison_functions.collections.trees.balanced_tree_from_sorted_array(array)¶

Uses the root node to create the binary tree


harrison_functions.collections.trees.binary_tree_from_array(array)¶

harrison_functions.collections.trees.binary_heap_from_array(array)¶

harrison_functions.collections.trees.binary_search_intervals(node, data)¶
Search a binary tree of intervals
Use with create_intervals and balanced_tree_from_sorted_array
       [5.0, 7.5]
       /         \
 [2.5, 5.0]  [7.5, 10.0]
    /
[0, 2.5]

harrison_functions.collections.trees.bucketer(array, intervals)¶
Sorts a list into a list of lists based on intervals, remainders are dropped
Use with create_intervals
>>> bucketer([64, 34, 25, 12, 22, 11, 90],
             [(0, 25.0), (25.0, 50.0), (50.0, 75.0), (75.0, 100.0)])

[[12, 22, 11], [34, 25], [64], [90]]

class harrison_functions.collections.trees.Node(data=None)¶

class harrison_functions.collections.trees.BinaryTree(root=None)¶
Make sure to only add Node objects to the Binary Tree
Examples:
  1. Using insert only
    source: https://www.tutorialspoint.com/python_data_structure/python_tree_traversal_algorithms.htm
           27
     /    \
   14      35
  /  \    /  \
10   19  31  42

tree = BinaryTree(Node(27))
tree.insert(Node(14))
tree.insert(Node(35))
tree.insert(Node(10))
tree.insert(Node(19))
tree.insert(Node(31))
tree.insert(Node(42))
  2. Impossible with insert only
    source: https://www.section.io/engineering-education/binary-tree-data-structure-python/
             10
       /    \
     34      89
    /  \    /  \
  20   45  56  54

tree = BinaryTree(Node(10))
tree.root.left = Node(34)
tree.root.right = Node(89)
tree.root.left.left = Node(20)
tree.root.left.right = Node(45)
tree.root.right.left = Node(56)
tree.root.right.right = Node(54)
binary_search(data)¶
count_leaf_nodes(node='default')¶

recursive count

insert(new_node)¶

level order insert

iterative_inorder(node='default')¶
See: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/inorder-tree-traversal-without-recursion/

  1. Create an empty stack.

  2. Initialize current node as root

  3. Push the current node to S and set current = current->left until current is NULL

  4. If current is NULL and stack is not empty then

    1. Pop the top item from stack.

    2. Print the popped item, set current = popped_item->right

    3. Go to step 3.

  5. If current is NULL and stack is empty then we are done.

Example

  1. add 27, add 14, add 10, pop 10, return 10, node.right=None

  2. pop 14, return 14, node.right=19

  3. add 19, pop 19, return 19, node.right=None

  4. pop 27, return 27, node.right=35

  5. add 35, add 31, pop 31, return 31, node.right=None

  6. pop 35, return 35, node.right=42

  7. add 42, pop 42, return 42, node.right=None

iterative_levelorder(node='default')¶

Add current level elements to stack and pop them to return

print_tree(method='recursive', order='inorder')¶
Valid options:
order: [‘inorder’, ‘preorder’, ‘postorder’]
method: [‘recursive’, ‘iterative’]
recursive_inorder(node='default')¶
traverse recursively
left -> root -> right
recursive_postorder(node='default')¶
traverse recursively
left -> right -> root
recursive_preorder(node='default')¶
traverse recursively
root -> left -> right
recursive_rev_inorder(node='default')¶
traverse recursively
right -> root -> left
search(data, order='levelorder')¶

Iterative search, this is bad for binary search trees


class harrison_functions.collections.trees.BinaryHeap(root=None)¶
Make sure to only add Node objects to the Binary Heap
Examples:
  1. Using insert only
    source: https://www.tutorialspoint.com/python_data_structure/python_tree_traversal_algorithms.htm
              2
       /    \
     10      9
    /  \    /
   5    6  1

heap = BinaryHeap(Node(2))
heap.insert(Node(10))
heap.insert(Node(9))
heap.insert(Node(5))
heap.insert(Node(6))
heap.insert(Node(1))
heapsort()¶
Only swaps one-layer deep
Traverses from bottom up in postorder
In the future: try to recurse down and place the new node at the right spot
For now, can just keep rerunning this, it will eventually sort itself
insert(new_node)¶
level order insert
See: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/insertion-in-a-binary-tree-in-level-order/
iterative_inorder(node='default')¶
See: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/inorder-tree-traversal-without-recursion/

  1. Create an empty stack.

  2. Initialize current node as root

  3. Push the current node to S and set current = current->left until current is NULL

  4. If current is NULL and stack is not empty then

    1. Pop the top item from stack.

    2. Print the popped item, set current = popped_item->right

    3. Go to step 3.

  5. If current is NULL and stack is empty then we are done.

Example

  1. add 27, add 14, add 10, pop 10, return 10, node.right=None

  2. pop 14, return 14, node.right=19

  3. add 19, pop 19, return 19, node.right=None

  4. pop 27, return 27, node.right=35

  5. add 35, add 31, pop 31, return 31, node.right=None

  6. pop 35, return 35, node.right=42

  7. add 42, pop 42, return 42, node.right=None

iterative_levelorder(node='default')¶
traverse iteratively
add current level elements to stack and pop them to return
recursive_inorder(node='default')¶
traverse recursively
left -> root -> right
recursive_postorder(node='default')¶
traverse recursively
left -> right -> root
swap(curr_node, child_node)¶

swap links on curr and child nodes update root if swap
